name: Domain Name System Security Extensions
summary: An extension to DNS that adds origin authentication, data integrity, and authenticated denial of existence using digital signatures. DNSSEC does not provide confidentiality.
purpose: Secure DNS responses by enabling clients to verify the authenticity and integrity of DNS data

handshake.description: DNSSEC uses the same query-response mechanism as DNS but adds digital signatures for validation. No handshake is required.
steps: Step 1: Client sends a DNS query for a domain with DNSSEC enabled.
Step 2: Resolver requests signed resource records from authoritative servers.
Step 3: Resolver validates the digital signatures against trusted keys (trust anchors).
Step 4: Resolver returns authenticated data to the client or indicates validation failure.

fields.name: RRSIG
fields.description: Contains the digital signature of a DNS record set

fields.name: DNSKEY
fields.description: Contains the public key used to verify RRSIGs

fields.name: DS (Delegation Signer)
fields.description: Links a child zone's DNSKEY to its parent zone for chain of trust

fields.name: NSEC / NSEC3
fields.description: Authenticated denial of existence for non-existent domain names

structure.payload: DNS resource records with RRSIG, DNSKEY, DS, and optional NSEC/NSEC3 records for validation

usage: Preventing DNS cache poisoning and spoofing
Authenticating the origin and integrity of DNS data
pitfalls: Does not provide confidentiality (queries and responses are still visible)
Increases message size due to digital signatures
Requires proper key management and trust anchor configuration
